s.text: For Rostenkowski, who is referred to only as "the Illinois Democrat who headed the Ways and Means Committee in 1990," being treated by the Times as an authority on politics, rather than as a news story himself, marks a giant step.

In these stories, as in countless others, Morris serves reporters by playing what they call a "trained seal"--a glib source who can be counted on to deliver an apposite quote to substantiate the thesis of any story.

For Rostenkowski, who is referred to only as "the Illinois Democrat who headed the Ways and Means Committee in 1990," being treated by the Times as an authority on politics, rather than as a news story himself, marks a giant step.
All these figures, brought down in political scandals, have nonetheless managed to re-establish themselves as players in Washington.
All these figures, brought down in political scandals, have nonetheless managed to re-establish themselves as players in Washington.
But reporters might ask whether they need to quote them at all.
But reporters might ask whether they need to quote them at all.
